Award.AwardTitle: Building Bridges: The Power of the Sisterhood

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: National data indicates that women from varied racial backgrounds desist from pursuing STEM careers at a higher rate than white women. Because diversity categorization often separates individuals by race and gender, women of color bear an additional discriminatory burden of this divisive effect in ways men and white women do not. Consequently, women of color face a double ration of exclusion. This project seeks to build stronger bonds between women of color and white women by addressing the elephant in the room: the lack of trust. By addressing the historical mistrust between women of different racial and ethnic backgrounds, we can develop a safe space to build trust. Mutually understood trust can then facilitate collaboration, alliances, and advocacy to come together and can translate into a critical mass of women in STEM fields.<br/><br/>This award will support two remote conferences on fostering dialogue between white women and women of color in engineering with the ultimate goal of increased retention of women in engineering. Groups of women from regions across the US will be convened for candid and open discussions about race, gender, and other social categories and how belonging to those categories shapes their experiences. Rather than focusing on best practices or tips and tricks, this project aims to deconstruct and reimagine these kinds of workshops to push participants to confront their own biases and ignorances. This project will bring together an unprecedented mix of participants to define research questions that can be further pursued and eventually lead to deeper understanding of how women in engineering, and then STEM, can become better allies to one another and make advancement toward their own representation. As the participants in this project return to their home institutions and offices, they will be able to share key takeaways with their circles and further increase the reach of this project. The results of the Building Bridges: Power of the Sisterhood pilot program have been shared in conference papers. Scaling the project will provide a greater opportunity to share knowledge via personal interactions, future conference proceedings, and publications for greater dissemination of critical information.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Building Bridges: The Power of the Sisterhood gathered a diverse group of attendees from academia, professional associations, and engineering non-profit agencies for two “un-conference” virtual gatherings held in 2020-2021. Each session included 42 women; the first session was held in November 2020 and hosted by the North Carolina State College of Engineering and the second session was held in January 2021 and hosted by the University of Cincinnati.

The project engaged women in engineering fields from across the United States in a candid and open dialogue about race, gender, and other social categories and how belonging to these categories shapes their professional experience.

URU The Right to Be, Inc.’s (URU) approach is premised on the theory that the way women understand and view themselves as individuals and in the collective informs how they engage with women whom they may not perceive as an ally. Not only do women enter collaborations with women holding internalized views of themselves and the groups to which they belong, e.g., self-doubt, imposter syndrome, views on advantage or disadvantage, perceptions of power and powerlessness, and so on; but they also do so in the contexts of mistrust, often viewing other women as competitors, using shorthand stereotypes to interpret the words and actions of other women who could be allies. These often-hidden notions may influence their ability to develop bonds which, in turn, influences the degree to which women create transformative networks and lasting alliances for industry and policy change. 

One primary outcome of Building Bridges: The Power of the Sisterhood is for the participants to have difficult conversations to make biases, reservations, and misunderstandings plain. We then work through these views to come up with alternative approaches that encourage women engineers to identify new and existing allies, to listen carefully to one another, and to find opportunities to get to know each other outside of labs and meeting rooms, therefore developing deeper and more enduring bonds. This foundational work helps women to create and sustain relationships with other professional women working in the engineering field to reach goals for broadening participation. URU’s research indicates that communication is the key activity needed to create and sustain partnerships. Participants' comments indicated that listening during intentional conversations builds relationships for change and transformation in the field of engineering.

 

In closing, participants were asked to describe two outcomes gained during the conference. The majority noted two pressing needs: to develop safe and brave spaces, and to create cultures of vulnerability. Most participants remarked how the conference changed their perception about how to affect institutional change led by a group of allies. Nearly half of the attendees reported that the conference changed their perception about how collaborations are a powerful technique to enact change in the field of engineering.
